info.game_comments:
Jared Hall game 2.
Last regular-play game of Season 29.

(1, 1).clue: Under California law, if this rental agreement covers more than 1 year, it must be in writing

(2, 1).clue: One who avoids the company of others

(5, 1).clue: Tyler took office in April 1841 following the passing of this man

(6, 1).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew reads the clue.)  In September 2013, Oracle Team USA takes up the defense of sailing's greatest prize, the America's Cup, when both teams of the competition will race these state-of-the-art multi-hulled vessels

(1, 2).clue: I need big rooms in my rental space, so I'm choosing one built before 1939 & thus called by this 6-letter term

(5, 2).clue: Tyler's administration ended the second of these Native American wars in Florida

(6, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew reads the clue.)  Standard training for the upcoming America's Cup includes flying a hull, a breathtaking maneuver that's used to increase speed & reduce this force that resists the motion of an object through a fluid

(1, 3).clue: "Owner Pays" means prospective landlords will pay this, the agent's fee to get a renter in

(2, 3).clue: One who helped kill St. Stephen

(5, 3).clue: A Maverick Democrat, Tyler defied this president & party leader in the early 1830s

(6, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reads the clue.)  One of the most physically demanding jobs aboard ship is the grinder, who performs the all-important task of trimming the sails using these top-handled devices

(1, 4).clue: Renters hope their new digs have plenty of these features that start with the way you end prayers

(2, 4).clue: I can barely read the page I just printed--will somebody replace this?!

(5, 4).clue: A veto by Tyler caused this whole group except Daniel Webster to quit in September 1841

(6, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue.)  Instead of a traditional fabric sail on a mast, vessels like the AC45 use a wing sail, a rigid structure predominantly made from this elemental fiber for its greater strength & lighter weight

(1, 5).clue: "EIK" is short for this, meaning there's actually room for a table

(2, 5).clue: From the Latin for "burdensome", this adjective means troublesome or difficult

(5, 5).clue: Tyler had a son at 63 who had a son at 75, so the President still has a living grandson in this Tyler home state

(6, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reads the clue.)  To make headway on a fixed course like the America's Cup, even when traveling into the wind, this maneuver turns a vessel's bows through the wind so that it flows from one side to the other

(1, 1).clue: The "Sir" before this mystery author's name came after his work as an army doctor during the Boer War

(2, 1).clue: "Here it is... your moment of Zen"

(3, 1).clue: In 1977 Roy & Gaye Raymond founded this lingerie chain, naming it after a very proper queen

(4, 1).clue: Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico & Utah meet at a monument known as this

(5, 1).clue: This warrior class was excluded from power in the 1870s & its privileged status dissolved

(6, 1).clue: This classic form of jazz developed in New Orleans in the early 20th Century & often features a banjo & trumpet

(1, 2).clue: Jockey & author Dick Francis flew a spitfire when he served with this group during World War II

(3, 2).clue: The somewhat mannish shirtwaist was popularized by this "girl" named for an illustrator

(4, 2).clue: The "4 Causes" of this Greek philosopher were the material, the formal, the efficient & the final

(5, 2).clue: On March 20, 1995 a cult released sarin gas in this city's subway system, killing a dozen people

(6, 2).clue: It can refer to a resident of Baghdad or Basra

(1, 3).clue: George Orwell was wounded while fighting for the losing Leftist side in this 1930s Civil War

(2, 3).clue: "And in the end the love you take is equal to the love you make"(2 people)

(3, 3).clue: This fashion weekly began publishing in 1867; it got the double "A" in 1929

(4, 3).clue: The third of Buddhism's 4 Noble Truths is the cessation of suffering commonly known as this

(5, 3).clue: In 1914 Japan joined the Allies & quickly seized this European power's islands in the Pacific

(6, 3).clue: A cutting remark, or a filament projecting from the shaft of a feather

(1, 4).clue: His time in the 488th Bombardment Squadron, 340th Bombardment Group inspired a classic satirical novel

(2, 4).clue: "Oh my God, they killed Kenny!"(2 people)

(3, 4).clue: Last name of Bologna siblings Marino, Maria &, of course, Bruno, taught the art of shoemaking by their grandpa

(4, 4).clue: The first H in 4-H, it's followed by Heart, Hands & Health

(5, 4).clue: The Meiji Constitution of 1889 created this 4-letter legislature with 2 houses

(6, 4).clue: Pass each arm under the other wrestler's arm & behind his neck in the "full" this hold; there's also a half type

(1, 5).clue: His time comforting wounded soldiers during the Civil War helped inspire his collection "Drum-Taps"

(3, 5).clue: Cushionet & bum roll were earlier names for this 19th Century device that pushed a skirt out in back

(4, 5).clue: The 4 of these were bile, blood, choler & phlegm

(5, 5).clue: From the 1630s to 1850s, this port on Kyushu served as Japan's only window to the Western World

(6, 5).clue: A not too chatty order of Cistercian monks, or a mild yellow cheese named for it

(0, 0).clue: The cover of the May 19, 1958 Time magazine called him "The Texan who conquered Russia"
